awd_titl_txt: The influence of doping and annealing onto the lattice dynamics, band structure and free charge carrier properties in monoclinic gallium aluminum oxide semiconductor alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: This project provides a scientific basis for development of novel semiconductor material for electronic devices that could enable real-time low-loss electric power distribution capability within the electric grid. Such distribution can be controlled by high-power electronic devices capable of switching and distributing high voltages and loads. As a new class of semiconductor materials, gallium aluminum oxide emerges as a promising candidate for fabrication of such devices. This project investigates the influence of doping and composition onto the resulting electronic properties of the material by employing a variety of theoretical and experimental characterization techniques. This project offers various training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, along with various outreach activities targeting K-12 students, teachers, minorities and underrepresented groups. The project includes Nebraska high-school and middle-school student summer research programs and after-school science education activities, and annual public Social and academic outreach programs are expanded to include demonstrations and Sunday presentations at the University of Nebraska State Museum on power electronics and the electric grid of the future for elementary to high school students.

Technical Description:  The project focuses on a fundamental material investigation of novel wide-bandgap material with potential in high power electronic applications. The research investigates the effect of doping and annealing on the electronic properties of semiconductor aluminum gallium oxide alloys with monoclinic symmetry. The main objectives are to determine the phonon, band structure and free charge carrier effective mass and mobility parameters, including their anisotropy, as a function of: (i) aluminum composition variation, (ii) tin, germanium and silicon doping concentrations and (iii) annealing under different gaseous environments in wide temperature ranges. The project combines computational theory and experimental characterization. Density functional theory calculations are performed to predict the effects of doping (defects) and alloying and to guide the applications of the experimental techniques - generalized spectroscopic ellipsometry and the optical Hall effect - to determine the electronic, phonon and transport properties in single crystals and heterostructures of low-symmetry semiconductors. Additional techniques include Raman spectroscopy and in-situ high-temperature studies. This research contributes to the technological development of high power electronic devices based on novel monoclinic semiconductor materials and provides education and research training possibilities for graduate students and young researchers in advanced semiconductor technology in culturally diverse environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This program developed new and broadly applicable understanding for the optical and optoelectronic properties of low-symmetry ultrawideband gap semiconductor materials. The PI and collaborators expanded the theory concept of eigenvalue perturbation analysis in Quantum Mechanics to low symmetry crystal structures and described the eigenvalue evolution of crystals with low symmetry under the influence of stress and strain. With this knowledge, the PI explained and demonstrated by experiment the peculiar evolution of the electronic band to band transitions in gallium oxide upon alloying with aluminum oxide. The PI also provided the first theoretical insight and support by experimental observation of how free charge carriers couple with lattice vibrations in crystals with low symmetry. From investigations of differently doped gallium oxide it was discovered that the density of free charge carries affects the amplitude and direction of lattice vibrations which are associated with dielectric loss conditions. These conditions are critically important for correct theoretical description of the charge transport properties in semiconductors. This program demonstrated the applicability of the new theoretical concepts to a wide variety of ultrawideband gap metal oxides such as lutetium oxyorthosilicate, yttrium oxyorthosilicate, and cadmium tungsten oxide, for example. A seminal paper also unraveled how lattice vibrations associated with electric dipole moments lead to reststrahlen bands unknown hitherto both from experiment and theory. The new theory explaining the infrared properties of low symmetry materials will become widely useful for correct interpretation of experimental as well as theoretical results for low-symmetry materials.

Broader Impact

The program resulted in unexpected discoveries of new physical properties of semiconductors with low crystal symmetry. For example, the PI and a group of collaborators demonstrated the existence of hyperbolic shear polaritons in low-symmetry crystals. These polaritons are coupled photon-lattice vibration waveforms, which propagate with shear motion under certain conditions at surfaces, interfaces, and within the bulk of such crystals. These new waveforms offer new building blocks in future solid state devices, which employ atomic vibrations and electromagnetic radiation for computation and data storage, for example. The results obtained from new theoretical and experimental understanding for electronic band-to-band transitions, their strain dependence, as well as their dependence on alloying are critically important for design of electronic device structures. Such structures are highly desired for high-power electronic applications. Such devices have received enormous attention currently due to the ongoing quest to transform our power generating and distributing infrastructure for a future with green energy. The program supported five graduate students of which two graduated with PhD. One minority PhD graduate became faculty member in a US higher education institution. One PhD entered the US workforce in semiconductor industry. The program supported six undergraduate students, four of which are from underrepresented backgrounds in engineering. The program also established new collaborations with national and international laboratories and student exchanges between the US and Sweden. This program has produced 39 original peer-reviewed journal papers. The program also established a new international lecture series on spectroscopic ellipsometry.
